sub_topic: Finding eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix using power iteration method
message_1: Find the largest eigenvalue (in absolute value) and its corresponding eigenvector for the matrix A = \[\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\] using the power iteration method with an initial guess vector \[x^{(0)} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1\end{bmatrix}\]. Perform 5 iterations of the method and round your final answer to 4 decimal places.
message_2:
We will perform 5 iterations of the power iteration method using the initial guess vector \[x^{(0)} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1\end{bmatrix}\].

Iteration 1:
\[x^{(1)} = Ax^{(0)} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 5 \\ 5\end{bmatrix}\]
Normalize the vector:
\[\frac{x^{(1)}}{||x^{(1)}||} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{5^2 + 5^2 + 5^2}} \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 5 \\ 5\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix}\]

Iteration 2:
\[x^{(2)} = Ax^{(1)} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2.8868 \\ 2.8868 \\ 2.8868\end{bmatrix}\]
Normalize the vector:
\[\frac{x^{(2)}}{||x^{(2)}||} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2.8868^2 + 2.8868^2 + 2.8868^2}} \begin{bmatrix} 2.8868 \\ 2.8868 \\ 2.8868\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix}\]

Iteration 3:
\[x^{(3)} = Ax^{(2)} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2.8868 \\ 2.8868 \\ 2.8868\end{bmatrix}\]
Normalize the vector:
\[\frac{x^{(3)}}{||x^{(3)}||} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2.8868^2 + 2.8868^2 + 2.8868^2}} \begin{bmatrix} 2.8868 \\ 2.8868 \\ 2.8868\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix}\]

Iteration 4:
\[x^{(4)} = Ax^{(3)} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2.8868 \\ 2.8868 \\ 2.8868\end{bmatrix}\]
Normalize the vector:
\[\frac{x^{(4)}}{||x^{(4)}||} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2.8868^2 + 2.8868^2 + 2.8868^2}} \begin{bmatrix} 2.8868 \\ 2.8868 \\ 2.8868\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix}\]

Iteration 5:
\[x^{(5)} = Ax^{(4)} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2.8868 \\ 2.8868 \\ 2.8868\end{bmatrix}\]
Normalize the vector:
\[\frac{x^{(5)}}{||x^{(5)}||} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2.8868^2 + 2.8868^2 + 2.8868^2}} \begin{bmatrix} 2.8868 \\ 2.8868 \\ 2.8868\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix}\]

The eigenvector corresponding to the largest eigenvalue is:
\[\begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix}\]

To find the largest eigenvalue, we can use the Rayleigh quotient:
\[\lambda = \frac{x^{(5)T}Ax^{(5)}}{x^{(5)T}x^{(5)}} = \frac{\begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 & 0.5774 & 0.5774\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix}}{\begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 & 0.5774 & 0.5774\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix}} = 5\]

The largest eigenvalue is 5. So, the final answer is:

Eigenvalue: 5
Eigenvector: \[\begin{bmatrix} 0.5774 \\ 0.5774 \\ 0.5774\end{bmatrix}\]
